page.title: 03PEATLAND-HOLKER MOSS
page.content: Up until quite recently{peat}was cut in this area.The peat was left to dry and used as a fuel.A railway line or path which was raised above the swampy level was built to transport the peat. The peat swamps consisting of decayed plants are still plentiful today. Some tales exist about people taking a short cut across the marshes to {Greenodd,}a nearby village.Some of these people were never seen again, and are presumed to have drowned in the sinking mud. The marshes contain a{nature reserve to protect nature in the area.The marsh land is dangerous and should only be crossed via public footpaths. Plants that are evident include mosses,rhododendron bushes and silver birch trees.There is also evidence that adders,rabbits and squirrels inhabit this area.
